comments:
I was just going from breakpoint to breakpoint, when Eclispe (M6) died.

(This total death on a single exception is very aggrevating. I'm sure you can 
come up with a better way of getting us to report bugs without tossing away 
the work-in-progress).

!MESSAGE Internal error logged from JDI Debug: 
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException
        at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.instructions.Instruction.popValue
(Instruction.java:115)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.instructions.PushFieldVariable.execute
(PushFieldVariable.java:49)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.Interpreter.execute
(Interpreter.java:50)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine$1
$EvaluationRunnable.run(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:303)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread.runEvaluation
(JDIThread.java:651)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine$EvalRunnable
.run(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:340)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread$ThreadJob.run
(JDIThread.java:2497)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:62)

I'm not sure the stack trace is releavant for the problem. Worker.run() handles
correctly all exceptions, not exception generated by a job would kill the VM.

Bob, are you sure this exception caused the VM to die ? Didn't you get any other
error in the console (if you were running from a console) ? Which VM are you using ?

Were you using conditionnal breakpoints ? or watch expressions ?
The stack trace was generated by an exception during an evaluation, it may be an
error that occured before the crash. Do you have any idea of which evaluation
could have generated this error ?

Well, since I wasn't stepping through the debugger in a debugger, I can't be 
certain that the exception in the log is really the one that killed it. Here's 
what I CAN say:

* The exception in the log was very close in time to when it died.
* It seems much more likely to die if I use conditional breakpoints, and I was 
using one when it died this time.
* I have since noted that I sometimes get deaths when debugging for which NO 
log entry occurs. This would support the idea that this wasn't the cause, but 
would also support the idea that there is an additional problem that is not 
logged.

Either way, there is a problem where fatal errors are not logged. (In the 
meantime, the log is flooded with stack traces for every unsuccessful attempt 
to contact an update site -- realy a separate report of course, but pointed 
out here for the sake of irony. I'll report it so you needn't bother 
separating this out ;=).

Bob: Can you try to launch Eclipse from a console, and try to crash it ? the VM
should print out data about why it died.

I just discovered the separate log files it dumps in the root directory when 
it crashes. It seems this is an access violation in the SWT native code. I 
guess that would make this a platform problem.
